awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Design of chalcogenide glass fiber devices for mid-IR applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Many threatening aerosol particles have unique spectral fingerprints in the mid-infrared (IR) region. Mid-IR sensors using this remarkable property are capable of identification, classification, and localization of a wide class of threatening, hazardous, and lethal particles, but methods for generating and transmitting mid-IR light are expensive and inefficient. The emerging technology of chalcogenide glass fiber devices promises to transform mid-IR sensor technologies, with potential benefit for millions of Americans whose lives are threatened by hazardous aerosol particles in their workplaces or from possible chemical attacks by terrorists. Advances in generating and transmitting mid-IR light have opened the possibility for inexpensive and efficient mid-IR sensors that continuously monitor threatening aerosol particles and transmit alerts to risk management and homeland security personnel in case of impending emergencies. This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project is to design chalcogenide fiber devices that will enable practical realization of sensor technologies with a variety of important applications such as biosensing, environmental monitoring, homeland security, and medical diagnostics. This project will broaden collaborations between academic researchers and the photonics industry. It will expand mentorship of underrepresented students by the principal investigator. It will also help the principal investigator to integrate research into university coursework and improve outreach efforts to local K-12 school students to spark interest in lasers/photonics and STEM fields. This project will help cultivate the research environment at the Baylor Research and Innovation Collaborative (BRIC), which is designed to foster interdisciplinary research between university faculty, industry partners, and area organizations. The outcome of this project will be disseminated through publications. The proposed research, undertaken in collaboration with industry partners, will lead to further commercial development of sensing components in the important mid-IR field.

Technical description: Our goal is to integrate modeling and prototyping in collaboration with industrial partners to determine the key factors that guide and support the development of reliable, cost-effective, and energy-efficient mid-IR spectroscopy. The primary challenge is to find the best fiber technology to generate and transmit mid-IR light sources in terms of efficiency, cost, power consumption, bandwidth, bend resistance, weight, and portability. To address this challenge, recent studies have identified the need for increased understanding of generation of mid-IR laser sources using chalcogenide glass fiber and delivery of high power mid-IR laser sources using chalcogenide negative curvature fibers. The research team's unique combination of expertise in optics and photonics, photonic crystal fibers, chalcogenide glass fibers, and computer modeling will permit the researchers to design efficient mid-IR chalcogenide glass fiber devices for a variety of applications. This program will lead to the creation of new applications that rely on high power lasers in the mid-IR region. The new negative curvature fibers with a broad transmission window will also transform the hollow core fibers to be used in devices with various potential applications. The comparison between theoretical models and experimental data will identify limiting factors in the devices and facilitate further improvements in experimental performance. The expected intellectual significance of the proposed project will be to turn the theory to practice for the devices in mid-IR applications including both generation and delivery of mid-IR light sources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many threatening aerosol particles can be identified by using lasers tuned for the mid-IR region to identify the particles’ unique spectroscopic signatures. The emerging technology of chalcogenide glass fiber devices promises to transform mid-infrared (IR) sensor technologies for millions of Americans whose lives can be threatened by hazardous aerosol particles in their workplaces or from possible chemical spills or chemical attacks. This technology can be exploited for chemical sensing, environmental monitoring, homeland security, and medical diagnostics. Advances in generating and transmitting mid-IR light have opened the possibility for inexpensive and efficient mid-IR sensors that continuously monitor threatening aerosol particles and transmit alerts to risk management and homeland security personnel in case of impending emergencies. The challenge is to find the best fiber technology to generate and transmit the required mid-IR laser light in terms of efficiency, cost, power consumption, bandwidth, bend resistance, weight, and portability. To address this challenge, many researchers are studying generation of mid-IR laser sources using chalcogenide glass fibers and delivery of high-power mid-IR laser light using chalcogenide negative curvature fibers.  The purpose of this project is to develop a comprehensive theoretical model, based upon both theory and results of empirical design tests, to be applied in the design of chalcogenide glass fiber devices. This project has significant intellectual merit because we have successfully designed negative curvature fibers for chalcogenide negative curvature fibers with curved arch structure for high-power delivery, negative curvature fibers for mid-IR fiber lasers, and fiber sensors. We have also studied the gas flow in gas-filled hollow-core fibers and the impact of geometry on leakage loss in negative curvature fibers made with chalcogenide glasses for carbon dioxide laser transmission. The theoretical findings have provided guidance regarding the optimum parameters to be used in the fiber drawing process. The comparison between the theoretical model and experimental data has already provided feedback to improve the experimental work. The experimental results from IRflex led to a commercial product, negative curvature fibers with anti-resonant arches. The collaborative work with AdValue Photonics, on mode analysis and thermal analysis in a waveguide structure pointed to the advantage of using a waveguide structure in experiments. This project serves as a successful example for the collaboration between the academic institution and private industry leading to innovative commercial projects.

Regarding the broader impacts of the project, the research and development associated with this project opened the possibility for inexpensive and efficient mid-IR sensors that could be used in a variety of safety and security settings. This research program has been integrated with Dr. Hu’s education plan through a combination of (i) broadening collaboration between academia and the photonics industry, (ii) integration of research into coursework, (iii) promoting mid-IR research among underrepresented and female students, and (iv) exhibiting optics demos to local K-12 school students. The students in the Photonics Research Laboratory at Baylor University gained a solid understanding of the nonlinear effect in optical fibers for mid-IR applications. The project helped them learn how to research the optimal configurations for mid-IR fibers and other related devices. The demonstrated work from chalcogenide negative curvature fibers shows promising results.

This project has potential significant impact on other disciplines. Mid-IR spectroscopy can provide information on a measured sample and can be used to study biological cells, fluids, and tissues. A tapered fiber with a tip of a subwavelength diameter can be used as a Scanning Near-Field Optical Microscope (SNOM). Mid-IR fibers can be combined with a well-established scanning probe microscopy (SPM) technique for a fiber-coupled spectroscopy technique. Fiber optics and SNOM represent a powerful synergy at the cutting edge of optical microscopy. Fiber optics, with their ability to transmit and manipulate light can serve as ideal components for SNOM setups. In our initial work on functional nanoscale tips, we have examined tip-enhanced Raman scattering (TERS), which can effectively enhance Raman signals by localized plasmon resonance on a nanoscale tip. These advantages make TERS an ideal technique for the chemical identification of single molecules. We anticipate that this technique can be extended to the high-resolution imaging of various nanostructures. Hence, the combined research of mid-IR fiber optics and SNOM has opened up new avenues for research in surface imaging, chemical sensing, and mid-IR fiber optics, promising significant breakthroughs in our understanding of nanoscale structures.
